text: card_id is an internal identifier for the payment instrument; it is primarily used for entity linkage and historical aggregation, not a standalone risk signal.
Transaction amount represents the value of the purchase; unusual magnitude relative to an account's historical spending may prompt additional review depending on context.
use_chip indicates whether EMV chip was used at POS; entry methods have different risk profiles and may inform review when combined with other factors.
merchant_id uniquely identifies the merchant entity; it supports history-based analysis (e.g., dispute rates) but is not determinative by itself.
merchant_state refers to the merchantâ€™s registered state; geographic consistency is evaluated relative to customer behavior and travel context.
zip is the merchant postal code; it can support location consistency checks but should be interpreted with other geo/device signals.
mcc (Merchant Category Code) denotes merchant type; certain categories show distinct dispute patterns and may warrant closer review in context.
card_brand/network can correlate with authorization flows and chargeback patterns; brand alone is not a conclusive risk indicator.
card_type (e.g., debit/credit/prepaid) affects usage and authorization rules; interpret relative to account history and channel.
expires indicates card expiration timing; lifecycle proximity may influence behavior but is not a standalone risk factor.
has_chip reflects EMV capability of the card; absence/presence influences terminal checks but does not imply fraud on its own.
num_cards_issued is the count of cards on the account; higher counts can be normal (household/business) and should be viewed with usage patterns.
credit_limit represents available exposure; unusual utilization patterns may prompt review depending on historical behavior.
acct_open_date indicates when the account was opened; tenure differences can affect baseline behavior and review thresholds.
year_pin_last_changed can indicate credential hygiene recency; stale credentials may combine with other factors to increase review likelihood.
card_on_dark_web flags external intelligence suggesting potential credential compromise; it is supportive context, to be corroborated with activity signals.
current_age may correlate with usage patterns but is a sensitive attribute; it should not drive adverse decisions and is mainly used for governance/fairness checks.
retirement_age is a planning/segmentation field; it should not be used directly for decisioning and is relevant primarily for analytics if permitted.
birth_year is a sensitive attribute; avoid use in decision logic. If present, restrict to compliance/fairness auditing per policy.
birth_month is a sensitive attribute; not intended for adverse decisions. Use only for aggregated analytics or governance where allowed.
gender is a sensitive attribute; it must not be used to make adverse decisions. Limit to bias monitoring and QA under governance controls.
latitude is merchant geolocation (paired with longitude); geo deviations can be travel-related and require contextual interpretation.
longitude complements latitude for merchant location; use alongside device/IP and customer itinerary indicators.
per_capita_income is area-level socioeconomic context; avoid inferring individual intent. Use cautiously per policy.
yearly_income relates to spending capacity; interpret only in context of historical behavior and approved policy constraints.
total_debt reflects liabilities; not a fraud label. If used, restrict to review prioritization policy and avoid standalone adverse decisions.
credit_score measures credit risk rather than fraud risk; do not equate score with fraudulent behavior. Use only as permitted by policy.
num_credit_cards is the number of credit cards held; evaluate relative to spending dispersion and account history.
merchant_type categorizes business activity; some types have higher dispute rates and may need additional review with supporting signals.
target is the internal training label used to approximate 'flagged for review'; it indicates routing to review and does not confirm fraud.
transaction_hour helps compare activity against typical user patterns; off-hours behavior may warrant review in context.
transaction_dayofweek informs routine vs deviation; differences alone are not determinative without corroborating factors.
Multiple small transactions within a short time window can indicate card testing behavior prior to a larger purchase; corroborate with device and location.
'Flagged' means routed for review under internal rules; it does not imply confirmed fraud. Explanations should describe reasons for flagging only.
When explaining a flagged case, cite the top contributing factors and connect them to known patterns or policies; avoid definitive fraud statements.
Evidence checklist: amount bin vs baseline, merchant category, geo consistency, device/entry method (chip/magstripe), account tenure, recent declines.
Sensitive attributes (e.g., gender, age buckets) must not be used for adverse decisions unless explicitly permitted; limit to fairness analysis and QA.
